4095518;Indsaml 2D fotografier og generer 3D data - fotogrammetri med Metashape;FALSE;2023-10-03T09:30:00+02:00;2023-10-03T16:00:00+02:00;"

*** Læs teksten på engelsk nedenfor ***
3D data har tilføjet nye dimensioner til kulturarvsområdet både i relation til dokumentation og i relation til formidling, og det er, hvad kurset skaber indblik i.

Fotogrammetri er når 3D data bliver skabt vha. 2D fotografier. Arkæologer bruger fotogrammetri til at gengive både små og store genstande, f.eks. skulpturer, runesten, heleristninger, udgravningsfelter og bygninger.
2D fotografier bliver indsamlet med almindelige spejlreflekskameraer, når det drejer sig om mindre genstande, og med droner, når det drejer sig om landsskabsmodeller.

3D data opstår ved at behandle fotografierne med software, og det er meget ofte programmet Metashape, som bliver brugt. 3D-modellerne føjer nye muligheder til arkæologers arbejde i relation til for- og fjernundersøgelser, formidling, inddragelse af VR osv. Du kan selv få indblik i mulighederne ved at deltage på kurset.

På kursuset bliver du introduceret til processen. Du er både med til at indsamle data i form af 2D fotografier og med til at genere 3D data. Kurset begynder på National Museet, hvor vi indsamler data. Dataindsamlingen foregår ved, at vi fotograferer udvalgte skulpturer i den antikke afdelingen. Kurset forsætter på KUB Datalab, Københavns Universitetsbibliotek, Søndre Campus, hvor vi
bearbejder data. Bearbejdningen foregår ved, at vi omskaber fotografierne til 3D data ved hjælp af nogle stærke gamer-computere og programmet Metashape.
Planen er i store træk således.
<ul>

column2: • 09:30 - Vi mødes ved personaleindgangen, hvor vi bliver modtaget af en museets medarbejdere og bliver guidet hen til samlingen af klassiske skulpterer og relieffer
• 10:00 - 12:00 - Vi indsamler data - dvs. tager billeder. Jeg medbringer tre kameraer, men har du selv et digitalt spejlreflekskamera, så er du velkommen til at medbringe dette.
• 12:00 - Vi siger farvel til National Museet og cykler / går til Søndre Campus
• 13:00 - 16:00 - Vi mødes i KUB Datalab SC og processerer modellerne.

column1: For at give et indtryk af, hvad det hele handler om, har jeg funder et par links til sites med
arkæologiske 3D modeller:
<ul>
Hvis der er deltagere, der ikke taler dansk, vil kurset blive afviklet på engelsk.
Collect 2D data and generate 3D data - photogrammetry with Metashape
3D data has added new dimensions to the field of cultural heritage both in relation to documentation and in relation to dissemination, and this is what the course creates an insight into.

Photogrammetry is when 3D data is created using 2D photographs. Archaeologists use photogrammetry to reproduce both small and large objects, e.g. sculptures, runestones, carvings, excavation sites and buildings.

2D photographs are collected with regular SLR cameras when it comes to smaller objects, and with drones when it comes to landscape models. 3D data is created by processing the photographs with software, and it is very often the program Metashape that is used.

The 3D models add new possibilities to archaeologists' work in relation to preliminary and remote investigations, communication, the inclusion of VR, etc. You can get an insight into the possibilities yourself by participating in the course.
On the course you will be introduced to the process. You both help to collect data in the form of 2D photographs and help to generate 3D data.

The course begins at the National Museum, where we collect data. The data collection takes place by photographing selected sculptures in the antique department. The course continues at KUB Datalab, Copenhagen University Library, Søndre Campus,
where we process data. The processing takes place by converting the photographs into 3D data using some powerful gamer computers and the program Metashape.
The plan is roughly as follows.
<ul>

column2: • 09:30 - We meet at the staff entrance, where we are received by a museum employee and are guided to the collection of classical sculptures and reliefs
• 10:00 - 12:00 - We collect data - i.e. taking pictures. I bring three cameras, but if you have a digital SLR yourself, you are welcome to bring this.
• 12:00 - We say a nice goodbye to the National Museum and cycle / walk to Søndre Campus
• 13:00 - 16:00 - We meet in KUB Datalab SC and process the models.

column1: To give an impression of what it's all about, I found a few links to sites with archaeological
3D models:
<ul>

If there are participants who do not speak Danish, the course will be conducted in English.2,

4083426;Ekstra Python 3 - Regulære udtryk;FALSE;2023-10-06T10:00:00+02:00;2023-10-06T12:00:00+02:00;"

Vil du fordybe dig i Python udover din undervisning?

Kursets formål er at give deltagerne kendskab til begrebet regulære udtryk og give eksempler på implemtering af regulære udtryk i python scripts. Workshoppen foregår i undervisningslokalet på føste sal på biblioteket på Søndre Campus.
Kursusmaterialet ligger her: https://github.com/lrskjr/extra_python
Inden kursets start bedes ud have downloadet og installeret Anaconda: https://www.anaconda.com/download
EN: Extra Python 3

Regular Expressions The purpose of the workshop is to gain a better understanding of the concept of regular expressions and to try implementing regular expressions in our Python scripts. The workshop takes place in the classroom on the first floor of the library at Søndre Campus.
Before starting the course, please download and install Anaconda: https://www.anaconda.com/download

The course material is located here: https://github.com/lrskjr/extra_python

4080211;NVivo - Introduktion til kvalitativ dataanalyse-software (QDAS);FALSE;2023-10-10T13:00:00+02:00;2023-10-10T15:00:00+02:00;"

Introduktion til programmet NVivo, som er en stor hjælp til kvalitativ dataanalyse. NVivo kan bl.a. hjælpe dig med at organisere og kode din empiri og litteratur, generere hypoteser, transskribere din lyd/video og meget andet.
PC-versionen af NVivo har mere udvidet funktionalitet end Mac-versionen, men man kan deltage i alle øvelser uanset version, og undervisningen vil ligeledes blive demonstreret i begge.
Du bedes forud for kurset have installeret den version af NVivo, der hedder NVivo 14.
Det kan du gøre her til Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Du bedes ligeledes forud for kurset gennemgå et par introducerende øvelser, som du kan læse om HER.
Gennemføres ved min. seks tilmeldte.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

4037369;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2023-10-11T12:30:00+02:00;2023-10-11T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4045220;Fjernlæsning i humaniora - Voyant Tools / Distant reading in the humanities - Voyant Tools;FALSE;2023-10-11T13:00:00+02:00;2023-10-11T15:00:00+02:00;"

*** For English read below ***

Praksis inden for humaniora har gennem de sidste mange år ændret sig. Et eksempel er, at den kendte praksis med at nærlæse og at skimme nu er ved at blive suppleret med at fjernlæse. Fjernlæse minder lidt om at skimme, men så er det alligevel også noget andet.
Når man fjernlæser, så fjerner man sig væk fra den enkelte side og ser materialet på afstand for at identificere mønstre, temaer, trends og særheder.

Redskaberne til fjernlæsning er foruden en computer og digitale tekster et begrænset antal algoritmer og mange visualiseringer. Nogle af de algoritmer og typer af visualiseringer, som bliver benyttet anvendes også inden for korpus lingvistik. Andre algoritmer og visuelle benyttes inden for statistik og bliver anvendt mange steder i samfundet til at løse alle typer af opgaver, der forudsætter en kategoriseringer og beregninger.

Fjernlæsning har fundet vej ind i humaniora med udbredelsen af digitale data i samfundet og i takt med, at kildemateriale er blevet digitaliset og fjernlæsningsredskaberne begynder at blive indarbejdet på websider til formidling og interaktion med tekstsamlinger.

Dette kursus er en introduktion til programmet Voyant Tools, der er udviklet til fjernlæsning og visualisering af tekstdata. Voyant Tools er et online program, så du skal ikke installere noget inden kurset. På kurset lærer du at gennem eksempler, hvordan du kan bruge Voyant Tools' visualiseringsredskaber i din praksis.
På kurset vil jeg tage udgangspunkt i mit datasæt bestående af 1800-tals, engelsk rejselitteratur, der omhandler de nordiske lande.
Hvis du ønsker at lære mere om at bruge en computer og Voyant Tools til at analysere tekster vil jeg denne bog:
<ul>

column2: • ()Rockwell, Geoffrey, and Stefan Sinclair. Hermeneutica: Computer-Assisted Interpretation in the Humanities. MIT Press, 2016.

column1: Vil du læse mere om Distant Readning vil jeg anbefale disse bøger:
<ul>

column2: • Underwood, Ted. Distant Horizons : Digital Evidence and Literary Change. Chicago, 2019.

column1: Hvis der er ikke-dansk-talene deltagere, vil kurset blive afviklet på engelsk.
Distant reading in the humanities - Voyant Tools

Practice within the humanities has changed over the past several years. One example is that the well-known practice of close reading and skimming is now being supplemented with distance reading. Distant reading is a bit like skimming, but then it's also something else.
When you read from a distance, you remove yourself from the individual page and view the material from a distance to identify patterns, themes, trends, and distinctive features.

The tools for distant reading are, in addition to a computer and digital texts, a limited number of algorithms and many visualizations. Some of the algorithms and types of visualizations that are used are also used within corpus linguistics.
Other algorithms and visuals are used in statistics and in many places in society to solve all types of tasks that require categorization and calculations

Distant reading has found its way into the humanities with the spread of digital data in society and as source material has been digitized. The distant reading tools are beginning to be incorporated into web pages for dissemination and interaction with text collections.

This course is an introduction to a program called Voyant Tools. It is developed to assist with  distant reading and visualization of text data. Voyant Tools is an online program, so you don't need to install anything before the course. In the course, you will learn through examples how you can use Voyant Tools' visualization tools in your practice.
In the course I use my data set consisting of 19th-century English travel literature dealing with the Nordic countries.
If you want to learn more about using a computer and Voyant Tools to analyze texts I would recommend this book:
<ul>

column2: • Rockwell, Geoffrey, and Stefan Sinclair. Hermeneutics: Computer-Assisted Interpretation in the Humanities. MIT Press, 2016.

column1: If you want to read more about Distant Reading, I would recommend these books:
<ul>

column2: • Underwood, Ted. Distant Horizons : Digital Evidence and Literary Change. Chicago, 2019.

column1:
If there are non-Danish-speaking participants, the course will be conducted in English.

4058826;Excel og samfundsvidenskabelig analyse;FALSE;2023-10-12T14:15:00+02:00;2023-10-12T16:00:00+02:00;"

Vil du gerne have styr på Microsoft Excel, så kig forbi til vores workshop på Gothersgade. Fokus er på brug af Excel til opgaver og studiet.
Excel er et stærkt talbehandlingsværktøj, der kan analysere og skabe overblik over store mængder data og vise dét, du vil fremhæve, i dine opgaver.

Vi introducerer Excels terminologi og gennemgår basisfunktioner, betinget formatering, sortering, tabeller, diagrammer m.m. Vi arbejder med større datasæt og avancerede værktøjer i form af pivottabeller og visualisering af data som tabeller og figurer m.m.
Vigtigt og praktisk inden kurset:
Kurset er for KU-studerende. Medbring din laptop (Windows/Mac) og hav Excel installeret (Excel 2013/2016/2019/365).
Du får et link til kursusmaterialet i Absalon 2 dage før kursusstart.
Vi forventer, at du har grundlæggende computer-færdigheder og erfaring med at bruge Microsoft-office, når du melder dig til kurset.
Gennemføres ved min. 5 tilmeldte.
Der er mindst tre kurser pr. semester. Hvis du er skrevet op, men ikke kan komme alligevel, så husk at melde fra, så er du sød (for der er tit kø).

4103286;Excel and social science analysis;FALSE;2023-10-17T14:15:00+02:00;2023-10-17T16:00:00+02:00;"

Want to get a quick and easy overview of you data? Then come to our workshop on Gothersgade. The focus is on using Excel for tasks and studies.

We introduce Excel terminology and cover basic functions, conditional formatting, sorting, tables, charts, and more. We work with larger datasets and advanced tools such as pivot tables and data visualization as tables and shapes, among others.
Important and practical information before the course:
The course is for University of Copenhagen students. Please bring your laptop (Windows/Mac) and have Excel installed (Excel 2013/2016/2019/365).
If you are using a different spreadsheet-software, we will not be able to support you.
You will receive a link to the course materials in Absalon 2 days before the course starts.
We expect you to have basic computer skills and experience using Microsoft Office when you sign up for the course.
The course will be conducted with a minimum of 5 participants.

If you are signed up but cannot attend, please remember to cancel, as there is often a waiting list.

4037370;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2023-10-18T12:30:00+02:00;2023-10-18T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4067241;R for Absolute Beginners;FALSE;2023-10-23T10:00:00+02:00;2023-10-23T12:00:00+02:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4080212;ONLINE: NVivo - Introduction to Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) (English);FALSE;2023-10-25T12:30:00+02:00;2023-10-25T15:00:00+02:00;"
Please note: This course will be held online via Zoom. A link will be sent to attendees.
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also ask you to complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

4042331;Text, data mining og Visual programming med Orange;FALSE;2023-10-25T13:00:00+02:00;2023-10-25T15:00:00+02:00;"

 *** For English see below ***
Orange er et nyt, sejt, open source dataminingsprogram, der giver en bred vifte af muligheder til den digitale humanist, der er til text og data mining uden at skulle kode algoritmerne fra bunden.
I Orange foregår databehandlingen ved, at du opbygger et workflow af "widgets", som er algoritmer, som bliver forbundet af "kanaler", som sørger for udveksliningen af data mellem algoritmerne.

Humanister og andre akademikere, der ikke er vant til at scripte i f.eks. Python eller R, oplever det som en fordel, at de ikke skal programmere, men kan behandle data ved at "dragge og droppe" algoritmer.

Det kan potentielt set frigive et overskud, der kan sætte ind på at forstå, hvad de forskellige algoritmer gør. I Orange kan brugerne både benytte egne data i form af tekst eller billeder, og de kan webscrape data fra for eksempel Pudmed, The Guardian, NY Times eller Wikipedia.

Programmet er udviklet ved University of Ljubljana, Slovenien, og udover sin smarte og visulelle funktionalitet er det meget veldokumenteret sammenlignet med andre open source-produkter. Dokumentationen består dels i  mange korte, informative videoer, dels i læsestof, der findes på Oranges officielle hjemmeside, hvorfra man også kan downloade programmet.
Hvis der er engelsktalene blandt de tilmeldte, bliver kruset afholdt på engelsk.

Orange is a new, cool, open source data mining program that provides a wide range of options for the digital humanist who is into text and data mining without having to code the algorithms from scratch.
In Orange, the data processing takes place by building a workflow of "widgets", which are algorithms which are connected by "channels", which ensure the exchange of data between the algorithms.
Humanists and other academics who are not used to scripting in e.g. Python or R, find it an advantage that they don't have to program, but can process data by  "dragging and dropping" algorithms.

It can potentially release a surplus that can be used to understand what the various algorithms do. In Orange, users can both use their own data in the form of text or images, and they can webscrape data from, for example, Pudmed, The Guardian, NY Times or Wikipedia.

The program was developed at the University of Ljubljana, Slovenia, and besides its smart and visual functionality, it is very well documented compared to other open source products. The documentation consists partly of many short, informative videos, partly of reading material that can be found on Orange's official website, from which you can also download the program.

If there are English speakers among those registered, the mug will be held in English.

S;NA;33563;Visualisation;9876;Lars Kjær;;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;20;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;20;8;0;0;8;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://libapps-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/customers/105/images/Orange_logo.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA

KUB Datalab inviterer dig til datasprint, hvor du har mulighed for at lære at bruge programmet Orange, som er et nyt, gratis program til computerbaserede undersøgelser af store datasæt, f.eks. historiske datasæt.

Datasprintet er en workshop for studerende, og forløber over to korte dage. Første dag er den 26. oktober kl. 14 - 18. Anden dag er den 27. oktober kl. 9-15. Begge dage forgår datasprintet på Københavns Universitetsbibliotek, Søndre Campus i undervisningslokalet på 1. sal.
Du lærer at bruge Orange ved at arbejde med tre datasæt om Oplysningstiden:
<ul>

column2: • Litteratur fra Det Kgl. Bibliotekets digitale samling 1750 - 1799.

column1: Med udgangspunkt i de tre datasæt er det din og de andre deltageres opgave i små grupper at fortage en undersøgelse og producere tre - fire grafer, som gruppen fremlægger ved datasprintets afslutning. De tre datasæt er interessante hver for sig, men det kunne også være interessant at lade de tre datasæt indgå i en samlet undersøgelse. Hvilke spørgsmål vil vi f.eks. kunne stille til Trykkefrihedens Skrifter med udgangspunkt i de befolkningsstatistikker, vi kan producere fra Folketællingen?
Lyder det som noget for dig, så foregår tilmelding til datasprintet fra denne side: https://datasprint.kb.dk/tilmelding
EN:

KUB Datalab invites you to a Data Sprint, where you have the opportunity to learn to use the program Orange, which is a new, free program for computer-based investigations of large datasets, for example historical datasets.

The Data Sprint is a workshop for students and takes place over two short days. The first day is on October 26th from 2 PM to 6 PM. The second day is on October 27th from 9 AM to 3 PM. Both days, the Data Sprint will be held at the University of Copenhagen's University Library, South Campus, in the classroom on the 1st floor.
You will learn to use Orange from working on three datasets about the Enlightenment era:
<ul>

column2: • Writings of Freedom of the Press (beginning of the 1770s).
• Literature from the Royal Library's digital collection 1750 - 1799.
• The Census from the National Archives in 1787.

column1: Based on these three datasets, it is your and the other participants' task in small groups to conduct an investigation and produce three to four graphs, which the group will present at the end of the Data Sprint. While each of the three datasets is interesting on its own, it could also be intriguing to incorporate all three datasets into a comprehensive investigation. What questions, for example, could we ask about the Writings of Freedom of the Press based on the population statistics we can derive from the Census?
If this sounds interesting to you, the registration for the Data Sprint can be done from this page: Data Sprint Registration

Datasprintet er en workshop for studerende, og forløber over to korte dage. Første dag er den 26. oktober kl. 14 - 18. Anden dag er den 27. oktober kl. 9-15. Begge dage forgår datasprintet på Københavns Universitetsbibliotek, Søndre Campus i undervisningslokalet på 1. sal.
Du lærer at bruge Orange ved at arbejde med tre datasæt om Oplysningstiden:
<ul>

column2: • Litteratur fra Det Kgl. Bibliotekets digitale samling 1750 - 1799.

column1: Med udgangspunkt i de tre datasæt er det din og de andre deltageres opgave i små grupper at fortage en undersøgelse og producere tre - fire grafer, som gruppen fremlægger ved datasprintets afslutning. De tre datasæt er interessante hver for sig, men det kunne også være interessant at lade de tre datasæt indgå i en samlet undersøgelse. 4067242;R and APIs - Statistics Denmark;FALSE;2023-10-30T10:00:00+01:00;2023-10-30T12:00:00+01:00;"

APIs provide access to a multitude of information.
In this course we cover how to extract data though APIs using the Statistics Denmark and i can haz dad joke APIs as examples.
The course material can be found on this website. Please make sure that you have followed the under "Setup" to install R and RStudio as well as some additional packages.
The course requires some previous knowledge of R. We will assume that you are familiar with:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself

column1:
These topics are covered in our introductory courses in R.

In this course we cover how to extract data though APIs using the Statistics Denmark and i can haz dad joke APIs as examples.
The course material can be found on this website. Please make sure that you have followed the under "Setup" to install R and RStudio as well as some additional packages.
The course requires some previous knowledge of R. We will assume that you are familiar with:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself

column1:
These topics are covered in our introductory courses in R.

4058827;Excel og samfundsvidenskabelig analyse;FALSE;2023-10-31T13:15:00+01:00;2023-10-31T15:00:00+01:00;"

Vil du gerne have styr på Microsoft Excel, så kig forbi til vores workshop på Gothersgade. Fokus er på brug af Excel til opgaver og studiet.
Excel er et stærkt talbehandlingsværktøj, der kan analysere og skabe overblik over store mængder data og vise dét, du vil fremhæve, i dine opgaver.

Vi introducerer Excels terminologi og gennemgår basisfunktioner, betinget formatering, sortering, tabeller, diagrammer m.m. Vi arbejder med større datasæt og avancerede værktøjer i form af pivottabeller og visualisering af data som tabeller og figurer m.m.
Vigtigt og praktisk inden kurset:
Kurset er for KU-studerende. Medbring din laptop (Windows/Mac) og hav Excel installeret (Excel 2013/2016/2019/365).
Du får et link til kursusmaterialet i Absalon 2 dage før kursusstart.
Vi forventer, at du har grundlæggende computer-færdigheder og erfaring med at bruge Microsoft-office, når du melder dig til kurset.
Gennemføres ved min. 5 tilmeldte.
Der er mindst tre kurser pr. semester. Hvis du er skrevet op, men ikke kan komme alligevel, så husk at melde fra, så er du sød (for der er tit kø).

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4058827;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4058827;0;0;;40;KUB City Campus, Gothersgade 140, 1123 København K;NA;32027;Datalab;38457;Nakisa Broby-Sobhdam;Erik Schwägermann & Nakisa Sobhdam;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;15;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;15;4;0;0;4;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://lcimages-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/data/feat_img/1069/6416/1649142564.png;NA;0;;30;30;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
This course is not an introductory course but presupposes a basic understanding of the functionality in NVivo.
This understanding can optionally be gained by participating in our introductory NVivo courses found here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/datalab
We will be working with transcription of audio files, the use of case classification, and import of transcribed interviews.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

4037373;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2023-11-01T12:30:00+01:00;2023-11-01T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4095913;R for Absolute Beginners;FALSE;2023-11-02T13:00:00+01:00;2023-11-02T15:00:00+01:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

4080299;Text mining with R;FALSE;2023-11-03T10:00:00+01:00;2023-11-03T12:00:00+01:00;"

In this course we will use the programming language R and learn how to use it for analysis of texts. The course includes how to clean and prepare texts for analysis, and how to visualize our analyses.
Text mining is a powerful set of methods for analyzing the themes and content of a large number of texts, and together with R's visualization capabilities we will learn how to visuliaze our findings
We will analyze speeches from debates in the Danish parliament Folketinget, including metadata about each speech, which will enable us to do more detailed and informative analyses

The course does not presume any experience with text mining methods, but we expect participants to have a bare minimum of experience with R, corresponding to the Datalab's introcourse "R for Absolute Beginners". We will use Rstudio, so you must have installed both R and Rstudio

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

4081331;Nvivo for your literature review;FALSE;2023-11-07T09:00:00+01:00;2023-11-07T11:30:00+01:00;"

The course "Nvivo for your literature review" builds on competencies and knowledge learned in our "Introduction to qualitative data analysis software (QDAS)". The introductory course is offered throughout the semester, in Danish and in English. Read more our Nvivo courses in the library's course calendar.

In Nvivo for your Literature Review we focus on analytical techniques useful for literature reviews. The techniques and discussions we cover during the course can also be used when writing articles, conference papers, and student assignments. This is because NVivo helps you organize and “code” (categorize) your literature, identify concepts and visualize relationships between them and document your method. It can also be helpful in generating hypotheses and generally getting an overview of your project.
At the end of the workshop participants will have learned and practised:
<ul>

column2: • setting-up an NVivo project: importing data from reference managers, creating folders, using case nodes, and classification attributes
• using basic analysis features of NVivo: creating parent and child nodes, reviewing and changing coding, adding annotations, applying links, and memoing
• performing queries and creating frameworks to allow you to compare coded material across different demographics or among themes

column1: Preperation for the workshop
Before the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
<ul>

column2: • This can be done here for Windows: https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe

column1: Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found in tthe Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
In case of any difficulties in this process, please contact Copenhagen University’s Service desk.
Please read the following carefully:
You need to do two things to prepare for the course
<ol>

column2: • Download the Nvivo sample project "Literature Review. Virtual reality and health". When you have installed Nvivo 14, open the programme up. On the welcome page you will see a link to "More Sample Projects". Click on this link to gain access to the sample project. You will have to log in to your Nvivo profile to download.
Short cut: Link to sample projects for Windows: https://help-nv.qsrinternational.com/20/win/Content/about-nvivo/explore-sample-project.htm
Short cut: Link to sample projects for MAC: https://help-nv.qsrinternational.com/14/mac/Content/about-nvivo/explore-sample-project.htm
• Have some PDF files in your chosen referencemanager. During the course, we will go through how to import files into Nvivo.

column1: Please find our Absalon course room HERE
Workshop design

The teaching is based on the PC version of NVivo, where especially for literature reviews the program works best. The Mac-version of the programme is not on the same level as the PC version, but you can of course attend the course with a Mac but there will be some functions not available for you to use.
<ul>
If you are interested in working with interview data in NVivo, please attend the advanced NVivo course NVivo og interviewdata
The course requires a minimum of five participants.
Related website with more workshops and tutorials

/Lorna Wildgaard (lowi@kb.dk)

4118160;R for Absolute Beginners - ONLINE;FALSE;2023-11-14T09:00:00+01:00;2023-11-14T11:00:00+01:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

4118160;R for Absolute Beginners - ONLINE;FALSE;2023-11-14T09:00:00+01:00;2023-11-14T11:00:00+01:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4080298;NVivo - Introduktion til kvalitativ dataanalyse-software (QDAS);FALSE;2023-11-21T10:00:00+01:00;2023-11-21T12:00:00+01:00;"

Introduktion til programmet NVivo, som er en stor hjælp til kvalitativ dataanalyse. NVivo kan bl.a. hjælpe dig med at organisere og kode din empiri og litteratur, generere hypoteser, transskribere din lyd/video og meget andet.
PC-versionen af NVivo har mere udvidet funktionalitet end Mac-versionen, men man kan deltage i alle øvelser uanset version, og undervisningen vil ligeledes blive demonstreret i begge.
Du bedes forud for kurset have installeret den version af NVivo, der hedder NVivo 14.
Det kan du gøre her til Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Du bedes ligeledes forud for kurset gennemgå et par introducerende øvelser, som du kan læse om HER.
Gennemføres ved min. seks tilmeldte.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

Note: This is part 1 of 2. For registration to part 2, visit here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4114954
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab?q=python

Note: This is part 1 of 2. For registration to part 2, visit here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4114954
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:

4117877;Indsaml 2D fotografier og generer 3D data - fotogrammetri med Metashape;FALSE;2024-01-22T09:30:00+01:00;2024-01-22T16:00:00+01:00;"

*** For English see below (non-Danish speaking participants are welcome) ***
3D data har tilføjet nye dimensioner til kulturarvsområdet både i relation til dokumentation og i relation til formidling, og det er, hvad kurset skaber indblik i.

Fotogrammetri er, når 3D data bliver skabt vha. 2D fotografier. Arkæologer bruger fotogrammetri til at gengive både små og store genstande, f.eks. skulpturer, runesten, heleristninger, udgravningsfelter og bygninger.
2D fotografier bliver indsamlet med almindelige spejlreflekskameraer, når det drejer sig om mindre genstande, og med droner, når det drejer sig om landsskabsmodeller.

3D data opstår ved at behandle fotografierne med software, og det er meget ofte programmet Metashape, som bliver benyttet. 3D-modellerne føjer nye muligheder til arkæologers arbejde i relation til for- og fjernundersøgelser, formidling, inddragelse af VR osv. Du kan selv få indblik i mulighederne ved at deltage på kurset.

På kursuset bliver du introduceret til processen. Du er både med til at indsamle data i form af 2D fotografier og med til at genere 3D data. Kurset begynder på Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, hvor vi indsamler data. Dataindsamlingen foregår ved, at vi fotograferer udvalgte skulpturer i udstillingen. Kurset forsætter på KUB Datalab, Københavns Universitetsbibliotek, Søndre Campus, hvor vi bearbejder data. Bearbejdningen foregår ved, at vi omskaber fotografierne til 3D data ved hjælp af nogle stærke gamer-computere og programmet Metashape.
Planen er i store træk således.
<ul>

column2: • 09:30 - Vi mødes ved Glyptotekets personaleindgang (se billedet nedenfor), hvor vi bliver modtaget af en medarbejder og bliver guidet hen til de skulpturer, som vi kan fotografere.
• 09:45 - 11:30 - Vi indsamler data - dvs. tager billeder. Jeg medbringer tre kameraer, men har du selv et digitalt spejlreflekskamera, så er du velkommen til at medbringe dette.
• 11:30 - Vi siger farvel til Glyptoteket og cykler / går til Søndre Campus
• 13:00 - 16:00 - Vi mødes i KUB Datalab SC og processerer modellerne.

column1: For at give et indtryk af, hvad det hele handler om, har jeg funder et par links til sites med arkæologiske 3D modeller:
<ul>
Hvis der er deltagere, der ikke taler dansk, vil kurset blive afviklet på engelsk. På billedet neden for er Glyptotekets personaleindgang market med en rød cirkel.
Collect 2D data and generate 3D data - photogrammetry with Metashape
3D data has added new dimensions to the field of cultural heritage both in relation to documentation and in relation to dissemination, and this is what the course creates an insight into.

Photogrammetry is when 3D data is created using 2D photographs. Archaeologists use photogrammetry to reproduce both small and large objects, e.g. sculptures, runestones, carvings, excavation sites and buildings.

2D photographs are collected with regular SLR cameras when it comes to smaller objects, and with drones when it comes to landscape models. 3D data is created by processing the photographs with software, and it is very often the program Metashape that is used.

The 3D models add new possibilities to archaeologists' work in relation to preliminary and remote investigations, communication, the inclusion of VR, etc. You can get an insight into the possibilities yourself by participating in the course.
On the course you will be introduced to the process. You both help to collect data in the form of 2D photographs and help to generate 3D data.

The course begins at The Glyptotek's, where we collect data. The data collection takes place by photographing selected sculptures in the exhibition. The course continues at KUB Datalab, Copenhagen University Library, Søndre Campus, where we process data. The processing is converting the photographs into 3D data using some powerful gamer computers and the program Metashape.
The plan is roughly as follows.
<ul>

column2: • 09:30 - We meet at the staff entrance of The Glypotek (see image below), where we are received by a museum employee and are guided to the collections
• 09:45 - 12:00 - We collect data - i.e. taking pictures. I bring three cameras, but if you have a digital SLR yourself, you are welcome to bring this.
• 12:00 - We say a nice goodbye to The Glyptotek's and cycle / walk to Søndre Campus
• 13:00 - 16:00 - We meet in KUB Datalab SC and process the models.

column1: To give an impression of what it's all about, I found a few links to sites with archaeological 3D models:
<ul>
If there are participants who do not speak Danish, the course will be conducted in English. In the picture below, the Glyptoteket staff entrance is marked with a red circle.

4117877;Indsaml 2D fotografier og generer 3D data - fotogrammetri med Metashape;FALSE;2024-01-22T09:30:00+01:00;2024-01-22T16:00:00+01:00;"

*** For English see below (non-Danish speaking participants are welcome) ***
3D data har tilføjet nye dimensioner til kulturarvsområdet både i relation til dokumentation og i relation til formidling, og det er, hvad kurset skaber indblik i.

Fotogrammetri er, når 3D data bliver skabt vha. 2D fotografier. Arkæologer bruger fotogrammetri til at gengive både små og store genstande, f.eks. skulpturer, runesten, heleristninger, udgravningsfelter og bygninger.
2D fotografier bliver indsamlet med almindelige spejlreflekskameraer, når det drejer sig om mindre genstande, og med droner, når det drejer sig om landsskabsmodeller.

3D data opstår ved at behandle fotografierne med software, og det er meget ofte programmet Metashape, som bliver benyttet. 3D-modellerne føjer nye muligheder til arkæologers arbejde i relation til for- og fjernundersøgelser, formidling, inddragelse af VR osv. Du kan selv få indblik i mulighederne ved at deltage på kurset.

På kursuset bliver du introduceret til processen. Du er både med til at indsamle data i form af 2D fotografier og med til at genere 3D data. Kurset begynder på Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, hvor vi indsamler data. Dataindsamlingen foregår ved, at vi fotograferer udvalgte skulpturer i udstillingen. Kurset forsætter på KUB Datalab, Københavns Universitetsbibliotek, Søndre Campus, hvor vi bearbejder data. Bearbejdningen foregår ved, at vi omskaber fotografierne til 3D data ved hjælp af nogle stærke gamer-computere og programmet Metashape.
Planen er i store træk således.
<ul>

column2: • 09:30 - Vi mødes ved Glyptotekets personaleindgang (se billedet nedenfor), hvor vi bliver modtaget af en medarbejder og bliver guidet hen til de skulpturer, som vi kan fotografere.
• 09:45 - 11:30 - Vi indsamler data - dvs. tager billeder. Jeg medbringer tre kameraer, men har du selv et digitalt spejlreflekskamera, så er du velkommen til at medbringe dette.
• 11:30 - Vi siger farvel til Glyptoteket og cykler / går til Søndre Campus
• 13:00 - 16:00 - Vi mødes i KUB Datalab SC og processerer modellerne.

column1: For at give et indtryk af, hvad det hele handler om, har jeg funder et par links til sites med arkæologiske 3D modeller:
<ul>
Hvis der er deltagere, der ikke taler dansk, vil kurset blive afviklet på engelsk. På billedet neden for er Glyptotekets personaleindgang market med en rød cirkel.
Collect 2D data and generate 3D data - photogrammetry with Metashape
3D data has added new dimensions to the field of cultural heritage both in relation to documentation and in relation to dissemination, and this is what the course creates an insight into.

Photogrammetry is when 3D data is created using 2D photographs. Archaeologists use photogrammetry to reproduce both small and large objects, e.g. sculptures, runestones, carvings, excavation sites and buildings.

2D photographs are collected with regular SLR cameras when it comes to smaller objects, and with drones when it comes to landscape models. 3D data is created by processing the photographs with software, and it is very often the program Metashape that is used.

The 3D models add new possibilities to archaeologists' work in relation to preliminary and remote investigations, communication, the inclusion of VR, etc. You can get an insight into the possibilities yourself by participating in the course.
On the course you will be introduced to the process. You both help to collect data in the form of 2D photographs and help to generate 3D data.

The course begins at The Glyptotek's, where we collect data. The data collection takes place by photographing selected sculptures in the exhibition. The course continues at KUB Datalab, Copenhagen University Library, Søndre Campus, where we process data. The processing is converting the photographs into 3D data using some powerful gamer computers and the program Metashape.
The plan is roughly as follows.
<ul>

column2: • 09:30 - We meet at the staff entrance of The Glypotek (see image below), where we are received by a museum employee and are guided to the collections
• 09:45 - 12:00 - We collect data - i.e. taking pictures. I bring three cameras, but if you have a digital SLR yourself, you are welcome to bring this.
• 12:00 - We say a nice goodbye to The Glyptotek's and cycle / walk to Søndre Campus
• 13:00 - 16:00 - We meet in KUB Datalab SC and process the models.

column1: To give an impression of what it's all about, I found a few links to sites with archaeological 3D models:
<ul>
If there are participants who do not speak Danish, the course will be conducted in English. In the picture below, the Glyptoteket staff entrance is marked with a red circle.

4119816;Python for let øvede: Tekstanalyse 1 - RegEX / Python for Intermediate Users: Text Analysis 1 - RegEX,;FALSE;2024-01-23T09:00:00+01:00;2024-01-23T10:30:00+01:00;"

English read below
​Tre nye Python-kurser er målrettet studerende, der er interesseret i tekstanalyse og Python.
Det første kursus, Python for let øvede: Tekstanalyse 1 - RegEX, handler om at søge i text strings vha. biblioteket RegEX.
Andet kursus, Python for let øvede: Tekstanalyse 2 - Pandas og Spacy, introducerer bibliotekerne Pandas og SpaCy og handler om dataframes og om at berige tekstdata med ordklasser.
Tredje kursus, Python for let øvede: Tekstanalyse 3 - Scikit-learn, handler om text mining, word embeddings, bag of words og maskinlæringsbiblioteket Scikit-learn.
Du skal tilmelde dig kurserne individuelt, og du kan frit vælge, om du vil deltage i et, to eller tre kurser.
Det er en fordel, men ikke et krav, at du har prøvet at programmere før. Hvis du er interesseret i grundlæggende Python, anbefaler vi, at du deltager i vores kursus "Python for Absolute Beginners".
Inden kursus bedes du have installeret Anaconda. Kurset bliver afholdt på engelsk, hvis der er engelsktalene deltagere.
English:
Three new Python courses are targeted at students interested in text analysis and Python.
The first course, Python for Intermediate Users: Text Analysis 1 - RegEX, is about searching in text strings using the RegEX library.

The second course, Python for Intermediate Users: Text Analysis 2 - Pandas and Spacy, introduces the Pandas and SpaCy libraries and is about dataframes and enriching text data with part-of-speech tags.
The third course, Python for Intermediate Users: Text Analysis 3 - Scikit-learn, is about text mining, word embeddings, bag of words, and the machine learning library Scikit-learn.
You must register for the courses individually, and you are free to choose whether you want to participate in one, two, or three courses.

It is an advantage, but not a requirement, that you have tried programming before. If you are interested in basic Python, we recommend that you participate in our course "Python for Absolute Beginners".

Before the course, please have  Anaconda installed. The course will be held in English if there are English-speaking participants.

4037385;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-01-24T12:30:00+01:00;2024-01-24T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4141101;Explorative data analysis with R;FALSE;2024-02-05T10:00:00+01:00;2024-02-05T12:00:00+01:00;"

How do you gain insight in your data? We explore a largish dataset using statistical methods and visualizations.
We assume that you have some experience working with R, and knows the tidyverse. The level required is what you would learn on one of our introductory course in "R for absolute beginners".
You should have R and Rstudio installed before the course, and preferably also have downloaded the dataset that we are going to explore. You can find further instructions here.

The course is by default held in Danish - unless one or more participants requests us to do it in English.

4141101;Explorative data analysis with R;FALSE;2024-02-05T10:00:00+01:00;2024-02-05T12:00:00+01:00;"

How do you gain insight in your data? We explore a largish dataset using statistical methods and visualizations.
We assume that you have some experience working with R, and knows the tidyverse. The level required is what you would learn on one of our introductory course in "R for absolute beginners".
You should have R and Rstudio installed before the course, and preferably also have downloaded the dataset that we are going to explore. You can find further instructions here.

The course is by default held in Danish - unless one or more participants requests us to do it in English.

4132925;NVivo - Introduction to Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) (English);FALSE;2024-02-07T10:00:00+01:00;2024-02-07T12:30:00+01:00;"
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also ask you to complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

4037387;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-02-07T12:30:00+01:00;2024-02-07T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

4132934;NVivo - Introduction to Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) (English);FALSE;2024-02-20T13:00:00+01:00;2024-02-20T15:30:00+01:00;"
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also ask you to complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4132934;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4132934;98;0;Library Lighthouse, zone 1;41;KUB Nørre Campus, Nørre Allé 49, 2200 København N;NA;33564;English;40172;Benjamin Derksen;Benjamin Derksen & Nynne Overlund;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;40;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;40;21;0;0;21;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://lcimages-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/data/feat_img/1069/6416/1674211150.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 1 of 2. For registration to part 2, visit here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4133591
or here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4182659
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab?q=python

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab?q=python

4183100;Digital Humaniora - tekst som data;FALSE;2024-02-28T09:30:00+01:00;2024-02-28T12:00:00+01:00;"

** For English see below **

Kurset "Introduktion til Digital Humaniora med fokus på tekst som data" giver mulighed at opnå en forståelse for begreber som "text mining" og "distant reading". På kurset tager vi udgangspunkt i brugervenlige programmer og hjemmesider. Vi kigger på avanceret brug af Google Ngram Viewer for at få en forståelse for distant reading og big data. Vi bruger Orange til at indsamle tekster fra The Guardian og Wikipedia, og vi taler nogle almindelige algoritmer til text mining på store datasæt. Med udgangspunkt i Voyant og Spyral forholder vi os til algoritmer og grafer til at gå i dybden med mindre tekstsamlinger.
Opnå kendskab til :
<ul>

column2: • distant reading med udgangspunkt i Google Ngram
• dataindsamling og analyse med udgangspunkt i Orange
• visualiseringer og formidling med udgangspunkt Voyant Tools og Spyral

column1: Kurset tager 2,5 timer med to korte pauser og veksler mellem korte oplæg efterfulgt af små øvelser.  Kurset foregår på KUB Søndre Campus i datalabbet på anden sal.
Kurset bliver afviklet på engelsk, hvis der er deltagere på kurset, der ikke taler dansk.
Digital Humanities - Text as Data

The course "Introduction to Digital Humanities with a focus on text as data" offers an opportunity to gain an understanding of concepts such as "text mining" and "distant reading". In this course, we will start with user-friendly programs and websites. We will look at advanced use of Google Ngram Viewer to understand distant reading and big data. We will use Orange to collect texts from The Guardian and Wikipedia, and we will discuss some common algorithms for text mining on large datasets. With a basis in Voyant and Spyral, we will delve into algorithms and graphs to go in depth with smaller text collections.
Gain knowledge in:
<ul>

column2: • Distant reading with a basis in Google Ngram
• Data collection and analysis with a basis in Orange
• Visualizations and dissemination with a basis in Voyant Tools and Spyral

column1: The course lasts 2.5 hours with two short breaks and alternates between brief lectures followed by small exercises. The course takes place at KUB Southern Campus in the data lab on the second floor.
The course will be conducted in English if there are participants who do not speak Danish.

Translated from Danish to English using AI.

4037390;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-02-28T12:30:00+01:00;2024-02-28T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

This course is not an introductory course but presupposes a basic understanding of the functionality in NVivo.
This understanding can optionally be gained by participating in our introductory NVivo courses found here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/datalab
We will be working with transcription of audio files, the use of case classification, and import of transcribed interviews.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4132935;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4132935;15906;0;KUB Datalab - Samf;40;KUB City Campus, Gothersgade 140, 1123 København K;NA;33564;English;28221;Daniel Pryn;Nynne Overlund & Daniel Pryn;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;22;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;22;20;0;0;20;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://lcimages-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/data/feat_img/1069/6416/1644571561.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 2 of 2. For registration to part 1, visit here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4133590
or here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4182656
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab?q=python

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

4037391;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-03-06T12:30:00+01:00;2024-03-06T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4190553;Digital Humaniora - tekst som data;FALSE;2024-03-11T11:30:00+01:00;2024-03-11T14:30:00+01:00;"

** For English see below **

Kurset "Introduktion til Digital Humaniora med fokus på tekst som data" giver mulighed at opnå en forståelse for begreber som "text mining" og "distant reading". På kurset tager vi udgangspunkt i brugervenlige programmer og hjemmesider. Vi kigger på avanceret brug af Google Ngram Viewer for at få en forståelse for distant reading og big data. Vi bruger Orange til at indsamle tekster fra The Guardian og Wikipedia, og vi taler nogle almindelige algoritmer til text mining på store datasæt. Med udgangspunkt i Voyant og Spyral forholder vi os til algoritmer og grafer til at gå i dybden med mindre tekstsamlinger.
Opnå kendskab til :
<ul>

column2: • distant reading med udgangspunkt i Google Ngram
• dataindsamling og analyse med udgangspunkt i Orange
• visualiseringer og formidling med udgangspunkt Voyant Tools og Spyral

column1: Kurset tager tre timer med to korte pauser og veksler mellem korte oplæg efterfulgt af små øvelser.  Kurset foregår på KUB Søndre Campus i datalabbet på anden sal.
Kurset bliver afviklet på engelsk, hvis der er deltagere på kurset, der ikke taler dansk.
Digital Humanities - Text as Data

The course "Introduction to Digital Humanities with a focus on text as data" offers an opportunity to gain an understanding of concepts such as "text mining" and "distant reading". In this course, we will start with user-friendly programs and websites. We will look at advanced use of Google Ngram Viewer to understand distant reading and big data. We will use Orange to collect texts from The Guardian and Wikipedia, and we will discuss some common algorithms for text mining on large datasets. With a basis in Voyant and Spyral, we will delve into algorithms and graphs to go in depth with smaller text collections.
Gain knowledge in:
<ul>

column2: • Distant reading with a basis in Google Ngram
• Data collection and analysis with a basis in Orange
• Visualizations and dissemination with a basis in Voyant Tools and Spyral

column1: The course lasts three hours with two short breaks and alternates between brief lectures followed by small exercises. The course takes place at KUB Southern Campus in the data lab on the second floor.
The course will be conducted in English if there are participants who do not speak Danish.

Translated from Danish to English using AI.

4132937;NVivo - Introduktion til kvalitativ dataanalyse-software (QDAS);FALSE;2024-03-11T12:00:00+01:00;2024-03-11T14:30:00+01:00;"

Introduktion til programmet NVivo, som er en stor hjælp til kvalitativ dataanalyse. NVivo kan bl.a. hjælpe dig med at organisere og kode din empiri og litteratur, generere hypoteser, transskribere din lyd/video og meget andet.
PC-versionen af NVivo har mere udvidet funktionalitet end Mac-versionen, men man kan deltage i alle øvelser uanset version, og undervisningen vil ligeledes blive demonstreret i begge.
Du bedes forud for kurset have installeret den version af NVivo, der hedder NVivo 14.
Det kan du gøre her til Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Du bedes ligeledes forud for kurset gennemgå et par introducerende øvelser, som du kan læse om HER.
Gennemføres ved min. seks tilmeldte.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

4037392;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-03-13T12:30:00+01:00;2024-03-13T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4192687;Pandas in Python - An Introduction to Structured Data Analysis;FALSE;2024-03-19T09:30:00+01:00;2024-03-19T12:30:00+01:00;"
Pandas is a Python library specifically designed for working with structured data such as data organised in rows and columns, similar to spreadsheets like Excel.
Pandas is useful for students across all fields of study, offering a toolkit for efficiently managing and analysing various types of structured data regardless of academic discipline.
In this three-hour course, you will develop an introductory understanding of Pandas. By the end of the course, you will have gained insights into the following areas:
<ul>

column2: • The types of data Pandas can handle
• Creating new datasets and subsets by filtering data

column1: This course is aimed at students who are new to Pandas but already have an introductory understanding of Python, such as can be gained from our “Python for Absolute Beginners” courses. We expect you to be familiar with the concepts described here:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
Note: Before the course, please download this dataset:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pandas-dev/pandas/main/doc/data/titanic.csv
