Dette kursus er ikke et introducerende kursus, men forudsætter en grundlæggende forståelse for NVivos funktioner.
Denne forståelse kan evt. fås via deltagelse i vores introducerende NVivo-kurser, som findes her:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/datalab
Vi kommer til at arbejde med transkribering af lydfiler, brug af cases og import af transkriberede interviews.
PC-versionen af NVivo har mere udvidet funktionalitet end Mac-versionen, men man kan deltage i alle øvelser uanset version, og undervisningen vil ligeledes blive demonstreret i begge.
Du bedes forud for kurset have installeret den version af NVivo, der hedder NVivo 14.
Det kan du gøre her til Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Gennemføres ved min. seks tilmeldte.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Gennemføres ved min. seks tilmeldte.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

4037394;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-03-27T12:30:00+01:00;2024-03-27T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4132940;ONLINE: NVivo - Introduction to Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) (English);FALSE;2024-04-03T10:00:00+02:00;2024-04-03T13:00:00+02:00;"
Please note: This course will be held online via Zoom. A link will be sent to attendees.
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also ask you to complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

Note: This is part 1 of 2. For registration to part 2, visit here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4133599
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab?q=python

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4133361;NVivo - Introduction to Qualitative Data Analysis Software (QDAS) (English);FALSE;2024-04-11T10:00:00+02:00;2024-04-11T12:30:00+02:00;"
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also ask you to complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.
The course requires a minimum of six participants.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4133361;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4133361;97;0;KUB Frederiksberg: Undervisningslokale I61;42;KUB Frederiksberg, Dyrlægevej 10, 1870 Frederiksberg C;NA;33564;English;28221;Daniel Pryn;Daniel Pryn & Erik Schwägermann;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;25;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;25;11;0;0;11;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://lcimages-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/data/feat_img/1069/6416/1674211150.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 2 of 2. For registration to part 1, visit here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4133598
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab?q=python

4037397;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-04-17T12:30:00+02:00;2024-04-17T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4175641;Text Mining with R;FALSE;2024-04-18T10:00:00+02:00;2024-04-18T12:00:00+02:00;"

In this course you will learn how to use text mining techniques with the programming language R to gain insights in to a large number of texts. Text mining is a set of powerful tools that allow you to make sense of a large set of texts and gain insights that are hard to spot by just reading the text yourself. You will also learn how to visualize your findings to showcase your results.
We will use summaries from the debates in the Danish parliament (Folketinget) as our data, but the tools and techniques that you learn can be used for text mining any set of texts.

You don't need any experience with text mining, but participants should have a basic knowledge about R, corresponding to our introductory course "R for Absolute Beginners". You must also have downloaded and installed R and Rstudio. Instructions on this can be found here

Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

4198297;Python and Pandas - Manage your rows and columns;FALSE;2024-04-18T12:30:00+02:00;2024-04-18T15:30:00+02:00;"
Pandas is a Python library specifically designed for working with structured data such as data organised in rows and columns, similar to spreadsheets in Excel.
Pandas is useful for students across all fields of study, offering a toolkit for efficiently managing and analysing various types of structured data regardless of academic discipline.
In this three-hour course, you will develop an introductory understanding of Pandas. By the end of the course, you will have gained insights into the following areas:
<ul>

column2: • Creating new datasets and subsets by filtering data

column1: This course is aimed at students who are new to Pandas but already have an introductory understanding of Python, such as can be gained from our “Python for Absolute Beginners” courses - pt. 1 and 2.
We expect you to be familiar with the concepts described here:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python-for-absolute-beginners/

4141102;R and APIs - Statistics Denmark;FALSE;2024-04-24T10:00:00+02:00;2024-04-24T12:00:00+02:00;"

APIs provide access to a multitude of information.
In this course we cover how to extract data though APIs using the Statistics Denmark and i can haz dad joke APIs as examples.
The course material can be found on this website. Please make sure that you have followed the under "Setup" to install R and RStudio as well as some additional packages.
The course requires some previous knowledge of R. We will assume that you are familiar with:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself

column1:
These topics are covered in our introductory courses in R.

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4202129;Introduktion til tekst- og datamining i Orange;FALSE;2024-04-25T13:00:00+02:00;2024-04-25T15:00:00+02:00;"
Orange er et program til tekst- og datamining, og det gode ved Orange er, at man kan bruge det uden at kunne programmere.
Orange-kurset kan anbefales, hvis du gerne vil have en forståelse for, hvordan data, som f.eks. digitale tekster og billeder, bliver transformeret i forbindelse med digital dataanalyse.

Til kurset har vi planlagt små eksemplariske opgaver om billed- og tekstanalyse, og vi giver korte introduktioner, som oplæg til øvelserne. Du får indblik i, hvordan du kan bruge Orange til at indsamle data og skabe systematik i store samlinger af tekst og billeder.
Vi berører vigtige begreber som embedding, vetorisering, distanceberegning, som udgør hjørnestenene i maskinlæring, tekst- og datamining.

Tilmeld dig via KUB Datalabs kalender . Der er 12 pladser. Du behøver ikke downloade og installere Orange inden kurset, da vi har installeret programmet på computerne i labbet på biblioteket på Søndre Campus.

4194788;Introduction to visualizing with ggplot2 in R;FALSE;2024-04-26T10:00:00+02:00;2024-04-26T12:00:00+02:00;"

Learn more about how you can visualize your data using R and RStudio. We cover the basics of ggplot2, including different types of plots, scales and facetting.
We expect that you have some experience using R, and tidyverse. The level of experience requiered is equivalent to the content of our introductory course in R, "R for absolute beginners".
The course material is published here, and we expect you to have R, RStudio and the tidyverse libraries installed. Instructions for this can be found here.

By default our courses are held in Danish, but if one or more learners request it, we will do it in English.

We expect that you have some experience using R, and tidyverse. The level of experience requiered is equivalent to the content of our introductory course in R, "R for absolute beginners".

By default our courses are held in Danish, but if one or more learners request it, we will do it in English.

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4194788;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4194788;21573;2;Library Lighthouse, Zone 1, Library Lighthouse, Zone 2;41;KUB Nørre Campus, Nørre Allé 49, 2200 København N;NA;33563;Visualisation;16332;Christian Knudsen;Christian Knudsen;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;25;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;25;3;0;0;3;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://libapps-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/customers/105/images/ggplot-logo.png;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

4133671;NVivo - Introduktion til kvalitativ dataanalyse-software (QDAS);FALSE;2024-04-30T12:30:00+02:00;2024-04-30T15:00:00+02:00;"

Introduktion til programmet NVivo, som er en stor hjælp til kvalitativ dataanalyse. NVivo kan bl.a. hjælpe dig med at organisere og kode din empiri og litteratur, generere hypoteser, transskribere din lyd/video og meget andet.
PC-versionen af NVivo har mere udvidet funktionalitet end Mac-versionen, men man kan deltage i alle øvelser uanset version, og undervisningen vil ligeledes blive demonstreret i begge.
Du bedes forud for kurset have installeret den version af NVivo, der hedder NVivo 14.
Det kan du gøre her til Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Du bedes ligeledes forud for kurset gennemgå et par introducerende øvelser, som du kan læse om HER.
Gennemføres ved min. seks tilmeldte.

/Erik Schwägermann (es@kb.dk) og Daniel Pryn (pryn@kb.dk)

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4182799;Searching for open data: Strategies and pitfalls;FALSE;2024-05-08T11:00:00+02:00;2024-05-08T12:30:00+02:00;"

Digital resources abound, but some are trickier to find and use than others, none more so than open data, which can be reused for new research projects.  In this course, we will put together some broad strategies for searching for open and accessible data, which can help to build up your research projects.  We will also cover issues in information literacy, bias, and trust when searching for data.  The session will end with a workshop, where attendees can either search for data that can butress an ongoing project, or they can search for supporting data to a couple of potential research questions to train the newly acquired strategies.  Information specialists will be on hand to guide and advise your searches.

4207550;KUB Datalab Orange Eurovision Dataset Workshop;FALSE;2024-05-22T09:30:00+02:00;2024-05-22T11:30:00+02:00;"
Orange is a program for text and data mining, and the great thing about Orange is that it can be used without any programming skills.
The Orange workshop is recommended if you want to understand how data, such as digital texts, are transformed in digital data analysis.

For the workshop, we have planned small exercises on text analysis, and we provide short introductions as a prelude to the exercises. You will gain insight into how you can use Orange to collect data and create systematics in large collections of texts and numbers.
The data for this workshop is this data set: "Measuring the {Eurovision Song Contest}: A Living Dataset for Real-World {MIR}" by John Ashley Burgoyne and Janne Spijkervet and David John Baker, 2023

We touch on important concepts such as embedding, vectorization, and distance calculation, which are cornerstones in machine learning, text, and data mining. Sign up via KUB Datalab's calendar. There are 12 spots available.
Please be aware that you need to download and install Orange before the course.

The workshop will be held in KUB Lighthouse Zone 1. Please use the library's main entrance and follow the signs.

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4207550;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4207550;21573;2;Library Lighthouse, Zone 1;41;KUB Nørre Campus, Nørre Allé 49, 2200 København N;NA;33562;Analysis;44253;Søren Davidsen;Søren Davidsen & Lars Kjær;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;12;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;12;8;0;0;8;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://dkou0skpxpnwz.cloudfront.net/customers/105/images/Orange_logo.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
4207550;KUB Datalab Orange Eurovision Dataset Workshop;FALSE;2024-05-22T09:30:00+02:00;2024-05-22T11:30:00+02:00;"
Orange is a program for text and data mining, and the great thing about Orange is that it can be used without any programming skills.
The Orange workshop is recommended if you want to understand how data, such as digital texts, are transformed in digital data analysis.

For the workshop, we have planned small exercises on text analysis, and we provide short introductions as a prelude to the exercises. You will gain insight into how you can use Orange to collect data and create systematics in large collections of texts and numbers.
The data for this workshop is this data set: "Measuring the {Eurovision Song Contest}: A Living Dataset for Real-World {MIR}" by John Ashley Burgoyne and Janne Spijkervet and David John Baker, 2023

We touch on important concepts such as embedding, vectorization, and distance calculation, which are cornerstones in machine learning, text, and data mining. Sign up via KUB Datalab's calendar. There are 12 spots available.
Please be aware that you need to download and install Orange before the course.

The workshop will be held in KUB Lighthouse Zone 1. Please use the library's main entrance and follow the signs.

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.
Please note that this course will be held in English if any participants request it. Otherwise it will be held in Danish.

4215816;For styr på 3D-rekonstruktioner i arkæologi: Flet modeller med Metashape og importer til Unreal Engine;FALSE;2024-06-17T13:00:00+02:00;2024-06-17T14:30:00+02:00;"

Den 17. juni fra kl. 13:00 til 14:30 i KUB Datalab på biblioteket på Søndre Campus afholder vi en spændende workshop målrettet arkæologistuderende, der ønsker at styrke kendskabet til den digitale udvikling, der rører sig inden for deres fag.

Som vi tidligere har annonceret, fokuserer workshoppen på benytte avancerede teknikker i Metashape til at flette to modeller sammen og på den måde skabe en fuld visning, så man både kan vise bunden og toppen af f.eks. en vase.

Vi vil også dykke ned i processen med at eksportere 3D-modeller og importere dem til Unreal Engine, der er et kraftfuldt 3D-computerspilprogram for at arbejde videre med modellerne der. Denne del tager Ph.D. i arkæologi, Mikkel Nørtoft, sig af.
Workshop bliver inspirerende og vil bidrage med nye perspektiver på, hvordan digitale værktøjer bidrager til arkæologisk forskning og formidling.

Der er kun få pladser, så tilmeldingen er nødvendig.

S;NA;32027;Datalab;9876;Lars Kjær;;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;5;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;5;5;0;0;5;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://dkou0skpxpnwz.cloudfront.net/customers/105/images/Metashape_logo.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;1022;Level 2 - Basic / Let øvet;NA;NA;NA;NA
4215816;For styr på 3D-rekonstruktioner i arkæologi: Flet modeller med Metashape og importer til Unreal Engine;FALSE;2024-06-17T13:00:00+02:00;2024-06-17T14:30:00+02:00;"

Den 17. juni fra kl. 13:00 til 14:30 i KUB Datalab på biblioteket på Søndre Campus afholder vi en spændende workshop målrettet arkæologistuderende, der ønsker at styrke kendskabet til den digitale udvikling, der rører sig inden for deres fag.

Som vi tidligere har annonceret, fokuserer workshoppen på benytte avancerede teknikker i Metashape til at flette to modeller sammen og på den måde skabe en fuld visning, så man både kan vise bunden og toppen af f.eks. en vase.

Vi vil også dykke ned i processen med at eksportere 3D-modeller og importere dem til Unreal Engine, der er et kraftfuldt 3D-computerspilprogram for at arbejde videre med modellerne der. Denne del tager Ph.D. i arkæologi, Mikkel Nørtoft, sig af.
Workshop bliver inspirerende og vil bidrage med nye perspektiver på, hvordan digitale værktøjer bidrager til arkæologisk forskning og formidling.

Der er kun få pladser, så tilmeldingen er nødvendig.

R et grenerelt programmeringssprog, som er særlig egnet til statistiske analyser og til rens og visualisering af data.
Vi forventer ikke, at du har nogen erfaring med programmering. Derfor tager vi udgangspunkt i nogle af R's helt grundlæggende funktionaliterer, som for eksempel:
<ul>

column2: • RStudios grænseflade og hvordan marn interagerer med R
• Enkle aritmetiske og logiske operationer på data
• At arbejde med funktioner og hvordan man selv skriver en enkel funktion
• Simple grafer, som ser lige så brugbare, som de er elementære.

column1: Forud for kurset beder vi dig om at installere R og RStudio eller at oprette en konto på rstudio.cloud. Du kan læse mere om, hvordan man gør, her. Her finder du også kursusmaterialet samt de øvelser, der gennemgåes på kurset.

4227299;AFLYST - Orange - text mining;FALSE;2024-09-03T13:00:00+02:00;2024-09-03T15:00:00+02:00;"<div class=""WACEditing EditMode EditingSurfaceBody FireFox WACViewPanel_DisableLegacyKeyCodeAndCharCode usehover"" contenteditable=""false"" id=""WACViewPanel_ClipboardElement"" spellcheck=""false"" style=""overflow: hidden; visibility: visible; direction: ltr;"" tabindex=""0"">
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">
Vi ved, at programmering kan være en barriere for mange der har en interesse i tekst- og datamining. Derfor holder vi et kursus i programmet Orange.
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">
Orange er et program til tekst- og datamining, og det gode ved Orange er, at man kan bruge det uden at kunne programmere. Denne type programmer kalder vi no-code-programmer.
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">

Orange-kurset kan anbefales, hvis du gerne vil have en forståelse for, hvordan data, som f.eks. digitale tekster og billeder, bliver transformeret i forbindelse med digital dataanalyse og maskinlæring.
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">

Til kurset har vi planlagt små eksemplariske opgaver, og vi giver korte introduktioner, som oplæg til øvelserne. Du får indblik i, hvordan du kan bruge Orange til at indsamle data og skabe systematik i store samlinger af tekst.
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">
Vi berører vigtige begreber som embedding, vetorisering, distanceberegning, som udgør hjørnestenene i maskinlæring, tekst- og datamining.
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">
Tilmeld dig via KUB Datalabs kalender. Der er 12 pladser.
<div class=""OutlineElement Ltr SCXW124391768 BCX2"" style=""direction: ltr;"">
Inden kurset beder vi dig downloade og installere programmet på din computer. Klik her for at komme til download-siden.

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4252262;Extra Python 1 - Strings, lists, and loops;FALSE;2024-09-06T09:00:00+02:00;2024-09-06T11:00:00+02:00;"

Extra Python 1
If you want to delve into Python scripting beyond classroom instruction, and you're interested in learning Python from a digital humanities approach, then this workshop series is for you.

At this workshop, there's an opportunity to become acquainted with some of the fundamental concepts in Python. This means variables, strings, lists, dictionaries and loops, built-in methods and functions, as well as 'for loops'.

The pedagogical starting point of the workshop is a practical, learning-by-doing approach. You must expect that you will have to write code yourself, type freely, make mistakes and ask for help to find the right key on the keyboard.
The code you will write is based on practical examples of how the digital humanist works with Python and text.

Before you attend the workshop please have access to Pýthon and either Jupyter Notebook or Jupyter Lab. You can use Erda, Google Colab or have a local Python installation. If you prefer your own installation, click this link for a guide on how to easily install Python on your own computer.
Find the course material on this github page.

4202465;R for Absolute Beginners;FALSE;2024-09-09T13:00:00+02:00;2024-09-09T15:00:00+02:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

Introduktion til programmet NVivo, som er en stor hjælp til kvalitativ dataanalyse. NVivo kan bl.a. hjælpe dig med at organisere og kode din empiri og litteratur, generere hypoteser, transskribere din lyd/video og meget andet.
PC-versionen af NVivo har mere udvidet funktionalitet end Mac-versionen, men man kan deltage i alle øvelser uanset version, og undervisningen vil ligeledes blive demonstreret i begge.
Du bedes forud for kurset have installeret den version af NVivo, der hedder NVivo 14.
Det kan du gøre her til Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
Og her til Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Benyt derefter registreringsnøgle fra KU’s Softwarebibliotek.
Bemærk: NVivo findes i Sofwarebiblioteket under linket "QSR International - NVivo".
Vi anbefaler desuden, at du gennemgår de første tre øvelser beskrevet HER.

Note: This is part 1 of 2. You can find part 2 in our course calendar:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab

4197834;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-09-11T12:30:00+02:00;2024-09-11T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4236749;Datasprint 2024 - dag 1;FALSE;2024-09-12T14:00:00+02:00;2024-09-12T18:00:00+02:00;"

Er du interesseret i at lære, hvordan du kan behandle, skabe systematik, omstrukturere og klargøre digitale kulturarvsdata til analyse og visualisering? Så er Datasprintet noget for dig!
Læs programmet for dag 1 her: Tid og sted | Datasprint (kb.dk)
<article data-id=""1353"" data-type="""">
<figcaption>
Foto: Lars Kjær
</figcaption>
Vi introducerer dig til forskellige metoder og software, der kan hjælpe dig med at arbejde effektivt med digitale data.
I løbet af workshoppen vil du få hands-on erfaring med følgende programmer:
OpenRefine
Et kraftfuldt værktøj til at rense og transformere data. OpenRefine gør det nemt at håndtere store datasæt og rette fejl, standardisere formater og udføre komplekse transformationer.
Python og/eller R
Populære programmeringssprog med biblioteker specielt designet til dataanalyse. Med Python og / eller R kan du manipulere, berige, analysere og visualisere dine data.
Orange
Et data mining program, der gør det muligt at udføre avancerede analyser og visualiseringer uden at skulle kode. Orange er ideelt til at udforske data og opdage mønstre og sammenhænge.
Kom og vær med

Formålet med workshoppen er at give dig redskaber og færdigheder til at fixe og behandle digitale data ved hjælp af programmerne. Uanset om du er nybegynder eller har lidt erfaring med dataanalyse, vil du opleve Datasprintet som en nyttig og lærerig oplevelse.
Tilmeld dig nu og bliv fortrolig med de værktøjer, der kan løfte dine datakompetencer til næste niveau!

</article>";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4236749;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4236749;14429;0;KUB Datalab - Sdr Campus;39;KUB Søndre Campus, Karen Blixens Plads 7, 2300 Kbh. Et data mining program, der gør det muligt at udføre avancerede analyser og visualiseringer uden at skulle kode. Orange er ideelt til at udforske data og opdage mønstre og sammenhænge.
Kom og vær med

Formålet med workshoppen er at give dig redskaber og færdigheder til at fixe og behandle digitale data ved hjælp af programmerne. Uanset om du er nybegynder eller har lidt erfaring med dataanalyse, vil du opleve Datasprintet som en nyttig og lærerig oplevelse.
Tilmeld dig nu og bliv fortrolig med de værktøjer, der kan løfte dine datakompetencer til næste niveau!

4251289;Explorative data analysis with R;FALSE;2024-09-17T10:00:00+02:00;2024-09-17T12:00:00+02:00;"

How do you gain insight in your data? We explore a largish dataset using statistical methods and visualizations.
We assume that you have some experience working with R, and knows the tidyverse. The level required is what you would learn on one of our introductory course in "R for absolute beginners".
You should have R and Rstudio installed before the course, and preferably also have downloaded the dataset that we are going to explore. You can find further instructions here.

The course is by default held in Danish - unless one or more participants requests us to do it in English.

4251289;Explorative data analysis with R;FALSE;2024-09-17T10:00:00+02:00;2024-09-17T12:00:00+02:00;"

How do you gain insight in your data? We explore a largish dataset using statistical methods and visualizations.
We assume that you have some experience working with R, and knows the tidyverse. The level required is what you would learn on one of our introductory course in "R for absolute beginners".
You should have R and Rstudio installed before the course, and preferably also have downloaded the dataset that we are going to explore. You can find further instructions here.

The course is by default held in Danish - unless one or more participants requests us to do it in English.

How do you gain insight in your data? We explore a largish dataset using statistical methods and visualizations.
We assume that you have some experience working with R, and knows the tidyverse. The level required is what you would learn on one of our introductory course in "R for absolute beginners".
You should have R and Rstudio installed before the course, and preferably also have downloaded the dataset that we are going to explore. You can find further instructions here.

The course is by default held in Danish - unless one or more participants requests us to do it in English.

Note: This is part 2 of 2. You can find part 1 in our course calendar:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab

4197835;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-09-18T12:30:00+02:00;2024-09-18T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4216239;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4216239;15906;0;KUB Datalab - Samf;40;KUB City Campus, Gothersgade 140, 1123 København K;NA;33564;English;28221;Daniel Pryn;Benjamin Derksen, Nynne Overlund & Daniel Pryn;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;25;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;25;25;0;0;25;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://libapps-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/customers/105/images/Python_logo.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;1021;Level 1 - Beginner / Begynder;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 1 of 2. You can find part 2 in our course calendar:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also recommend that you complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.

4252273;Extra Python 2 - Dataanalysis with Pandas;FALSE;2024-09-27T09:00:00+02:00;2024-09-27T11:00:00+02:00;"

Extra Python 2
If you want to delve into Python scripting beyond classroom instruction, and you're interested in learning Python from a digital humanities approach, then this workshop series is for you.

The purpose of the workshop is to enhance familiarity with Pandas dataframes and the most commonly used functions. Pandas is a 'must' if you use Python for working with data that is organized and structured in rows and columns.

The pedagogical starting point of the workshop is a practical, learning-by-doing approach. You must expect that you will have to write code yourself, type freely, make mistakes and ask for help to find the right key on the keyboard.
The code you will write is based on practical examples of how the digital humanist works with Python and text.

Before you attend the workshop please have access to Pýthon and either Jupyter Notebook or Jupyter Lab. You can use Erda, Google Colab or have a local Python installation. If you prefer your own installation, click this link for a guide on how to easily install Python on your own computer.

Find the course material on this github page.

This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4216243;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4216243;15906;0;KUB Datalab - Samf;40;KUB City Campus, Gothersgade 140, 1123 København K;NA;32027;Datalab;28221;Daniel Pryn;Benjamin Derksen, Nynne Overlund & Daniel Pryn;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;25;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;25;23;0;0;23;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://libapps-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/customers/105/images/Python_logo.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;1021;Level 1 - Beginner / Begynder;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 2 of 2. You can find part 1 in our course calendar:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python

4216276;NVivo - Cases and Classification in Interview Data;FALSE;2024-10-02T10:00:00+02:00;2024-10-02T12:30:00+02:00;"
This course is not an introductory course but presupposes a basic understanding of the functionality in NVivo.
This understanding can be gained by participating in our introductory NVivo courses found here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/datalab
In this course, we will expand upon the skills gained in our introductory course (https://absalon.ku.dk/courses/71442/), and we will be applying cases and case classification to qualitative data.
We will base the course examples on interview data, but both cases and case classifications can be applied to many other types of data.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".

4197837;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-10-02T12:30:00+02:00;2024-10-02T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4252276;Extra Python 3 - Regular Expression;FALSE;2024-10-04T09:00:00+02:00;2024-10-04T11:00:00+02:00;"

Extra Python 3
If you want to delve into Python scripting beyond classroom instruction, and you're interested in learning Python from a digital humanities approach, then this workshop series is for you.
The purpose of the workshop is to gain a better understanding of the concept of regular expressions and to try implementing regular expressions in our Python scripts.

The pedagogical starting point of the workshop is a practical, learning-by-doing approach. You must expect that you will have to write code yourself, type freely, make mistakes and ask for help to find the right key on the keyboard.
The code you will write is based on practical examples of how the digital humanist works with Python and text.

Before you attend the workshop please have access to Pýthon and either Jupyter Notebook or Jupyter Lab. You can use Erda, Google Colab or have a local Python installation. If you prefer your own installation, click this link for a guide on how to easily install Python on your own computer.

Find the course material on this github page.

4202466;R for absolutte nybegyndere;FALSE;2024-10-08T10:00:00+02:00;2024-10-08T12:00:00+02:00;"

Læg venligst mærke til, at kurset holdes på dansk.
Please note that this course will be held in Danish. For courses in English, please visit the datalab course calendar.
R et grenerelt programmeringssprog, som er særlig egnet til statistiske analyser og til rens og visualisering af data.
Vi forventer ikke, at du har nogen erfaring med programmering. Derfor tager vi udgangspunkt i nogle af R's helt grundlæggende funktionaliterer, som for eksempel:
<ul>

column2: • RStudios grænseflade og hvordan marn interagerer med R
• Enkle aritmetiske og logiske operationer på data
• At arbejde med funktioner og hvordan man selv skriver en enkel funktion
• Simple grafer, som ser lige så brugbare, som de er elementære.

column1:

R et grenerelt programmeringssprog, som er særlig egnet til statistiske analyser og til rens og visualisering af data.
Vi forventer ikke, at du har nogen erfaring med programmering. Derfor tager vi udgangspunkt i nogle af R's helt grundlæggende funktionaliterer, som for eksempel:
<ul>

column2: • RStudios grænseflade og hvordan marn interagerer med R
• Enkle aritmetiske og logiske operationer på data
• At arbejde med funktioner og hvordan man selv skriver en enkel funktion
• Simple grafer, som ser lige så brugbare, som de er elementære.

4216248;Python and Pandas - Getting Started with Data Analysis;FALSE;2024-10-09T12:00:00+02:00;2024-10-09T15:00:00+02:00;"
This course is aimed at students who are new to Pandas but already have an introductory understanding of Python, such as can be gained from our “Python for Absolute Beginners” courses - pt. 1 and 2.
We expect you to be familiar with all the concepts described under "Python for Absolute Beginners" here:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python
Pandas is a Python library specifically designed for working with structured data such as data organised in rows and columns, similar to spreadsheets in Excel.
Pandas is useful for students across all fields of study, offering a toolkit for efficiently managing and analysing various types of structured data regardless of academic discipline.
In this three-hour course, you will develop an introductory understanding of Pandas. By the end of the course, you will have gained insights into the following areas:
<ul>

column2: • Creating new datasets and subsets by filtering data

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4248258;Digital Humanities - Culture and Text;FALSE;2024-10-11T12:00:00+02:00;2024-10-11T16:00:00+02:00;"

Don't miss this unique opportunity to gain insight into different ways in which computer technology is being used as a tool in humanities research. In the DHCult network we have gathered five researchers who are looking forward to presenting how they use the computer in research in different projects.
Click here to register to participate online.
The program follows below.
<hr />
12:00 – 12:05
Introduction to the conference.
*
12:05 - 12:25
Cognitive Modeling as method for researching the mind – possibilities and limitations. Theory of Mind modeling as example.
Peter Thestrup Waade. Onsite. PhD Student. Aarhus University.

Cognitive modeling is a formal and computational approach to researching an understanding the (human) mind, methodologically rooted in the natural sciences but belonging to psychology, psychiatry, and the humanities in terms of subject matter. Giving an approach to describe mental mechanisms that underlie observable behavior, cognitive modeling provides tools for formal and data-driven accounts of the mind – but also comes with many limitations. In this talk, I use Theory of Mind modeling as an illustrative example of the method, both its advantages and disadvantages.
12:25 - 12:30: Questions
*
12:35 - 12:55
Digital Humanities between Ambition and Pragmatism
Jonas Kjøller-Rasmussen. Onsite. Information Specialist and PhD Student. University of Copenhagen

The combination of source accessibility and digital tools has inspired many novel and ambitious approaches to traditional humanities scholarship. Ambition, however, might sometimes yield to pragmatism when unfolded within the constraints of academic project management. In my presentation I will give a practical example of how high ambitions for the application of digital methods, when faced with obstacles, can be transformed into practical approaches that nonetheless provide valuable and unique insights that support and enhance traditional humanities scholarship at a fundamental level.
12:55 - 13:00: Questions
*
13:05 - 13:35
Read, search and Research. Using Trinskribus on a 18th century handwritten large scale source material
Tine R. Reeh. Onsite. Associate Professor. University of Copenhagen

This paper presents some of the experiences from using Transkribus in an interdisciplinary and collective research project; Managing Melancholy. After a brief explanation of our aims and approach, I will give some examples from our work. Finally, I will touch on unexpected obstacles and opportunities that may inspire and inform other projects.
13:35 - 13:45: Questions
*
13:45 - 14:00: Break
*
14:00 – 14:35
Digital humanities, infrastructure, and multilingual inclusivity
Paul Spence. Online. Reader in Digital Humanities. King’s College London

Recent years have seen a growing interest in the concept of Multilingual digital humanities, but what does DH understand by multilingualism, and how does DH research respond to the challenges which digital mediation presents for language diversity, language justice and language professionals? In this presentation, I will explore how Multilingual DH 'infrastructural' or 'workflow' responses engage with wider discussions about fostering epistemic diversity and global inclusivity in knowledge infrastructures.
14:35 – 14:45: Questions
*
14.45 - 15:00: Break
*
15:00 – 15:40
Voyant and Spyral
Geoffrey Rockwell. Online. Professor of Philosophy and Digital Humanities. University of Alberta

Voyant is a suite of text analysis and visualization tools that are widely used in the digital humanities, especially when introducing students to computer-assisted analysis of texts. In this presentation Geoffrey Rockwell will provide a brief history of Voyant leading up to the development of Spyral, a notebook programming extension to Voyant. He will demonstrate both Voyand and Spyral and discuss how Spyral provides a growth path for students and research projects. He will end by encouraging you to join the Voyant Consortium so that the tool evolves in ways that suit your research.
15:40 – 15:55: Questions
*
15:55 – 16:00
Goodbye
Click here to register.

Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4227300;Orange - Text and data mining in a user-friendly software;FALSE;2024-10-22T13:00:00+02:00;2024-10-22T15:00:00+02:00;"

Are you fascinated by text and data mining?
Take part in the KUB Datalab workshop and learn about it using a user-friendly program called Orange.
The workshop is relevant for both students and researchers who will be using or assessing digital methods and results.

Orange can be used for many data science tasks. The advantage of Orange is that it is a no-code software, that handles many of the same tasks and processes that are integrated parts of the concepts of data science that typically is applied to different fields of studies within both natural, social and humanistic science.
On the course you can learn:

4216279;ONLINE: NVivo for Absolute Beginners (macOS);FALSE;2024-10-23T09:30:00+02:00;2024-10-23T12:30:00+02:00;"
Please note: This course is for macOS users. We have an online course for Windows users here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also recommend that you complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.

4216278;ONLINE: NVivo for Absolute Beginners (Windows);FALSE;2024-10-23T09:30:00+02:00;2024-10-23T12:30:00+02:00;"
Please note: This course is for Windows users. We have an online course for macOS users here:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
Introduction to NVivo; a program which is a great help when you are working with qualitative data analysis.
NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also recommend that you complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.

4197840;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-10-23T12:30:00+02:00;2024-10-23T14:30:00+02:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4253162;Text mining with R;FALSE;2024-10-25T10:00:00+02:00;2024-10-25T12:00:00+02:00;"

Text mining is a powerful set of methods that enable us to process, analyze and visualize the content of a large number of texts. It gives us the possiblity to gain insights and spot patterns that can otherwise be hard to see when reading through the texts. The methods that you will learn on this course can be used to analyze any set of texts.

The advantage of R is that we have a lot of flexibility for our analysis and how we visualize our results. On this course you will learn how to prepare texts for analysis, and how to peform the analysis and visualize the results. Out texts will be summaries from debates in the Danish Parliament Folketinget.
We assume that you have some experience working with R, and knows the tidyverse. The level required is what you would learn on one of our introductory course in "R for absolute beginners".
You should have R and Rstudio installed before the course, and preferably also have downloaded the dataset that we are going to explore. You can find further instructions here.

The course is by default held in English, unless everyone speaks Danish, in which case it will be in Danish

4202468;R for Absolute Beginners - ONLINE;FALSE;2024-10-29T09:00:00+01:00;2024-10-29T11:00:00+01:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

NVivo can be useful, if you want to organise and/or code your empirical material or literature. It can also be helpful when you want to transcribe audio- or video files, generate hypotheses etc.
The PC version of NVivo has more functionality than the Mac version, but you can participate in all exercises with either and we will demonstrate in both.
Prior to the course, you must install the version of NVivo called NVivo 14.
This can be done here for Windows:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14/NVivo.x64.exe
And here for Mac:
https://download.qsrinternational.com/Software/NVivo14forMac/NVivo.dmg
Registration key is available through the UCPH Software Library.
Please note: NVivo can be found int the Software Library under the link "QSR International - NVivo".
We also recommend that you complete a set of introductory exercises before course start, that you can read about HERE.

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4216263;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4216263;97;0;KUB Frederiksberg: Undervisningslokale I61;42;KUB Frederiksberg, Dyrlægevej 10, 1870 Frederiksberg C;NA;33564;English;28221;Daniel Pryn;Benjamin Derksen, Daniel Pryn & Erik Schwägermann;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;25;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;25;9;0;0;9;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://lcimages-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/data/feat_img/1069/6416/1674211150.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;1021;Level 1 - Beginner / Begynder;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 1 of 2. You can find part 2 in our course calendar:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab

4197841;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-10-30T12:30:00+01:00;2024-10-30T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4202469;R for Absolute Beginners;FALSE;2024-11-05T13:00:00+01:00;2024-11-05T15:00:00+01:00;"

R is a general programming language, especially suited for statistical analysis and cleaning and visualization of data.
We assume absolutely no previous experience with programming, and will cover the basics of getting started with R, including:
<ul>

column2: • Navigating in RStudio, and how to interact with R
• Simple arithmetic and logical operations on data
• Working with functions - and how to write a very simple function ourself
• And how to make a couple of the common graphs, that are as useful as they are elementary.

column1: In preparation for the course, we recommend that you either download and install R and RStudio, or register for an account at rstudio.cloud. Instructions on this can be found here, where you will also find the course notes, additional material and exercises.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

Please note that this course will be held in english if any participants requests it. Otherwise it will be held in danish.

";https://kubkalender.kb.dk/event/4202469;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/aevent.php?c=6416&m=edit&event_id=4202469;21573;2;Library Lighthouse, Zone 1;41;KUB Nørre Campus, Nørre Allé 49, 2200 København N;NA;33564;English;16332;Christian Knudsen;Christian Knudsen;6416;KUB Datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab;https://kubkalender.kb.dk/admin/calendar/6416;25;TRUE;5673;FALSE;TRUE;TRUE;25;18;0;0;18;TRUE;#18E0F2;https://libapps-eu.s3.amazonaws.com/customers/105/images/R_logo.jpg;NA;0;;0;0;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA
Note: This is part 2 of 2. You can find part 1 in our course calendar:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab
This course is intended for students who have never tried programming before and want to build their skills in Python from the bottom up.

Intimidated by mathematics, numbers, and obscure Python scripts? Don’t be! We will be covering all the very basic concepts and building blocks in order to get complete beginners, who have no experience writing code, working in Python.

This will include explaining the concepts of variables and data types, as well generating some basic scripts to interact with these data, such as lists, loops, and conditionals. By the end of this course, you will have an understanding of the basic building blocks in Python. You will also come away with an appreciation for how a computer program “thinks”. All we require from you is a will to learn. We look forward to seeing you!
The course is divided in two parts. The first covers different datatypes in Python and how data is stored. In other words, it is an introduction to the building blocks of coding in Python.

The second part expands on this by putting these blocks together to create simple scripts. If you already have some understanding of Python, feel free to skip the first section. Otherwise, we recommend that you start with pt. 1 and then move on to pt. 2.

Practical information: We will be working in Jupyter Lab / Jupyter Notebook, which requires some installation, but you can also work in either Google Colabs or ERDA which require only a Google or KU account, respectively. For more information and help, consult "Install & Run Python" on the course page:
https://kubdatalab.github.io/python
As written, this course is an introduction to the basics of Python. If you have never programmed before, this is a good place to start before you move on to some of our more advanced courses:
https://kubkalender.kb.dk/calendar/datalab

4197842;Åbent værksted i Labbet / drop in consultations at KUB Datalab;FALSE;2024-11-06T12:30:00+01:00;2024-11-06T14:30:00+01:00;"

Having problems importing data? Or cleaning it? Is the structure weird, or are you getting strange error messages when you try to fit a model?
Drop in with your data and your problem, and we will do our best to help you. We offer no opinions on what statistical test you should run on your data. But we will get it to work.

No registration required, we try to assist everyone, but if necessary on a "first-come, first-served" basis

4227301;Orange - Data Mining for Absolute Beginners;FALSE;2024-11-11T09:30:00+01:00;2024-11-11T11:30:00+01:00;"

We know that programming can be a barrier for many who are fascinated by text and data mining. Therefore, we are hosting a course on the program Orange.

Orange is a user-friendly software for text and data mining, and the great thing about Orange is that you can use it without needing to know how to program. We call this type of program ‘no-code’ software.

The course is recommended if you want to understand how data, such as digital texts and images, can be transformed and analysed by a computer. In this way the course is relevant for both students and researchers who will be using or assessing digital methods and results.

Orange can handles many of the same tasks and processes that are integrated parts of the concepts of data science that typically is applied to different fields of studies within both natural, social and humanistic science.
On the course you can learn:
